However, unlike N132D, 1987A is currently undergoing the free expansion stage. The diameter of the circle formed by the rings is only 1 light year (NASA 2017f sec. 1). Over the past 30 years, the rings have brightened. The cause for this is currently unknown, however scientists hypothesize that the rings may have collided with the earlier solar wind ejected by the progenitor star prior to the explosion (NASA 2017f sec. 1).
